title: Genetic Association of Waist-to-Hip Ratio With Cardiometabolic Traits, Type 2 Diabetes, and Coronary Heart Disease
author: Emdin
author_address: Center for Genomic Medicine, Massachusetts General Hospital, 185 Cambridge St, CPZN 5.830, Boston, MA 02114
hypothesis: Effect of waist hip ratio adjusted for body mass index on cardiometabolic traits
rationale: In observational studies, abdominal adiposity has been associated with type 2 diabetes and coronary heart disease (CHD). Whether these associations represent causal relationships remains uncertain.
exposure_pleiotropy: To test assumption 2 (independence of polygenic risk score for WHR adjusted for BMI from potential confounders, Figure 1), the relationship of the polygenic risk score to smoking, alcohol use, physical activity, vegetable consumption, red meat consumption, and breastfeeding status as a child was determined among individuals in the UK Biobank
limitations_overall: List four main ones: pleiotropy, mislassification of 35 phenotypes, power, and restriction to Europeans
limitations_pleiotropy: Discussed in limitations: "First, although a number of approaches were used in an attempt to rule out pleiotropy, it is possible that these results represent a shared genetic basisbetweenWHRadjustedforBMIandCHDrather than a causal relationship."
limitations_population_stratification: Don't discuss, but do say in the methods: "The inclusion of principal components of ancestry as covariates is commonly implemented to correct for population stratification according to ancestral background."
notes: The way this paper is written makes it difficult to work out what has been done

title: Genetic association between adiposity and gout: a Mendelian randomization study
author: Larsson
author_address: Unit of Nutritional, Epidemiology, Institute of Environmental Medicine, Karolinska, Institutet, 171 77 Stockholm, Sweden.
hypothesis: Effect of body mas index and waist hip ratio adjusted for body mass index on gout and serum urate concentrationusing
rationale: Gout inflicts substantial morbidity by causing severe pain and is associated with an increased risk of death and is paralleled with the rise in obesity trend, suggesting excess adiposity may be a risk factor for gout but the literature is inconsistent.
outcome_definition: Usually by questionnaire of gout or medication but defined differently
exposure_n_difference_reason: MATT - Not mentioned; having said that - I think the number in column AC ("N" from original GWAS is wrong). In the Shungin paper, they say they have information from 142762 with GWAS data and 81697 with Metabochip = 224459
exposure_population: They seem to use information from all ancestries for their main analyses but then restrict to the SNPs associated with each exposure within just Europeans for a sensitivity analyses to check that population stratification wasn't a problem
exposure_independence: Those that were genome-wide significant within all ancestries (49) then limited to the SNPs found in only European individuals (39).
exposure_pleiotropy: Not in the GWAS but in the current paper, authors used weighted median and MR-Egger regression plus heterogeneity statistics using Cochran's Q test
n_SNP_difference_reason: MATT - not mentioned but I think the 49 is correct though
multiple_testing: Bonferroni-correction of 0.05/14 = 0.0125 to reflect two adiposity measures and two outcomes
limitations_overall: We could not assess the associations of adiposity with gout and serum urate concentrations separately for men and women, with potentially different fat accumulation in different locations.
limitations_pleiotropy: The possibility that pleiotropy (i.e. the genetic association with the outcome is through a different causal pathway and not through the exposure of interest) may have influenced the results cannot entirely be ruled out. However, the genetic association between BMI and risk of gout was similar in sensitivity analyses and there was no evidence of pleiotropy.
limitations_population_stratification: Bias due to population stratification is unlikely to explain the observed associations because BMI was positively associated with gout and serum urate concentrations in analyses restricted to data from 77 SNPs associated with BMI in European-ancestry individuals.
notes: Just a note that the figure says that the odds ratio for gout is 0.96 but the table says 0.97

title: Genetic association between adiposity and gout: a Mendelian randomization study
author: Larsson
author_address: Unit of Nutritional, Epidemiology, Institute of Environmental Medicine, Karolinska, Institutet, 171 77 Stockholm, Sweden.
hypothesis: Effect of body mas index and waist hip ratio adjusted for body mass index on gout and serum urate concentrationusing
rationale: Gout inflicts substantial morbidity by causing severe pain and is associated with an increased risk of death and is paralleled with the rise in obesity trend, suggesting excess adiposity may be a risk factor for gout but the literature is inconsistent.
outcome_definition: Usually by questionnaire of gout or medication but defined differently
exposure_population: This is their sensitivity analyses - where the authors restrict to the SNPs associated with each exposure within just Europeans to check that population stratification wasn't a problem
exposure_independence: Those that were genome-wide significant within all ancestries (49) then limited to the SNPs found in only European individuals (39).
exposure_pleiotropy: Not in the GWAS but in the current paper, authors used weighted median and MR-Egger regression plus heterogeneity statistics using Cochran's Q test
n_SNP_difference_reason: MATT - not mentioned but I think the 49 is correct though
multiple_testing: Bonferroni-correction of 0.05/14 = 0.0125 to reflect two adiposity measures and two outcomes
limitations_overall: We could not assess the associations of adiposity with gout and serum urate concentrations separately for men and women, with potentially different fat accumulation in different locations.
limitations_pleiotropy: The possibility that pleiotropy (i.e. the genetic association with the outcome is through a different causal pathway and not through the exposure of interest) may have influenced the results cannot entirely be ruled out. However, the genetic association between BMI and risk of gout was similar in sensitivity analyses and there was no evidence of pleiotropy.
limitations_population_stratification: Bias due to population stratification is unlikely to explain the observed associations because BMI was positively associated with gout and serum urate concentrations in analyses restricted to data from 77 SNPs associated with BMI in European-ancestry individuals.
